title: Cat. 20  Side Panel of a Sarcophagus, first half of the 3rd century A.D.
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Side Panel of a Sarcophagus  
First half of the 3rd century A.D.  
Roman  
Marble; 96 × 140.5 × 22 cm (37 5/16 × 55 3/8 × 8 5/8 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of the Alsdorf Foundation, 1983.584

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">This panel once functioned as the left side panel of a large stone sarcophagus. It is decorated at the uppermost part with a cornice of ornamental bands comprising a Lesbian cymation, an egg-and-dart pattern, and a bead-and-reel motif, below which is a scene depicting five figures. At the center stands a nude male figure with long, wavy hair, who gazes to his left (fig. 20.1). He rests his right foot on what might have been a rock, while a chlamys, which appears to have been wrapped behind him and around his left arm, rests on his elevated right thigh. No traces of attributes are present in either of his arms, which are largely fragmentary from the shoulders down.

On the far left is a muscular, nude male figure, who sits upright on a chlamys-covered seat (fig. 20.2). His arms extend forward slightly to hold a knobby wooden club that rests between his legs. At his back is a small tree, the placement of which marks the leftmost edge of the panel (fig. 20.3).

The pose of this figure is echoed in that of the fragmentary female figure on the right, who is similarly shown seated in an erect position. Although lacking the head and arms, much of the figure’s body is preserved. Here she is shown nude from the waist up, with a chiton covering her lower body as well as the rocky seat upon which she rests (fig. 20.4). Traces of her right arm suggest that she was pulling her chiton upward, perhaps toward her face.

In between these three main figures stand two cloaked men, both of whom were armed: the figure on the left holds a spear with his raised right arm (fig. 20.2), while the figure on the right appears to have also held a spear, as suggested by the remains of a spearpoint projecting from the cornice (fig. 20.4).

At the right edge of the panel is a partially preserved horse, with traces of its reins remaining around the neck. Around the right corner is a fragmentary male figure, who presumably led the horse (fig. 20.5). Above these figures, one finds the continuation of the ornamental cornice, which indicates that these figures formed the leftmost edge of one of the long sides of the rectangular sarcophagus. This side panel would likely have been completed on its bottom edge with another decorative band, which is now missing.

Based on the large scale of this panel as well as its ornamental cornice, it has been identified as belonging to an Attic sarcophagus. Such sarcophagi, which were produced in Athens and were primarily designed for export, are characterized by their rich relief carving on all four sides and their emphasis on Greek mythological subjects, including episodes associated with such heroes as Herakles, Meleager, and Achilles as well as scenes from the Trojan Wars. The subject of the scene depicted on this side panel is rather unusual, which has resulted in a number of scholarly interpretations over the last several decades.

The prevailing interpretation, which was originally proposed by Guntram Koch, is that it depicts a scene with the Greek mythical hero Meleager and his fellow hunters during the Calydonian boar hunt. This identification is based largely on this panel’s notable formal similarities to the side panel of a sarcophagus from Arles, now in Autun, France, which depicts five figures in a comparable arrangement (fig. 20.6). The Autun panel’s identification with the subject of Meleager is based primarily on the fact that its front panel depicts the mythical boar hunt. According to Koch, in both the Chicago and Autun panels, the central standing nude figure is identified as Meleager, while the remaining figures represent his hunting companions. The seated, partially nude woman at the right is therefore his beloved, the huntress Atalanta.

In another interpretation, Cornelius Vermeule suggested that the scene might depict the glorification of Alexander the Great, with the famed king standing in the company of the seated Herakles on the left, a seated nymph or personification on the right, and two standing companions flanking Alexander, one of which might have been his general and close friend, Hephaistion. The head of the standing central figure bears a striking resemblance to a portrait of Alexander the Great in Los Angeles (fig. 20.7), both of which are characterized by wavy, leonine hair; upturned, gazing eyes; and a leftward orientation of the head (fig. 20.8). Moreover, the central figure’s pose, with the right leg elevated on a rock, resembles the statuary type known as the Alexander Rondanini (fig. 20.9). Vermeule later proposed a conflation of the Alexander and Meleager interpretations, suggesting that the Chicago panel might depict Alexander the Great in the guise of Meleager, given that both were renowned for their conquests and their tragic deaths.

Recently, Sandra Knudsen has offered a persuasive new interpretation of the Chicago panel, in which the scene depicts the Greek god Hermes (the Roman Mercury) in his rescue of Io, the daughter of the river Inachus, from the monster Argus. Following this reading, Hermes is the standing figure at the center, who faces the seated Argus to the left. The god’s pose is reflected in a statuary type described by modern scholars as the “sandal-binder,” which has been associated with the representation of Hermes, as one finds in this statue in Copenhagen (fig. 20.10). To the right of Hermes is the seated Io, whose partial nudity serves as a clue to her captivity, as she pulls her chiton upward in her right hand as if in distress. While this particular scene appears to be elsewhere unattested on Roman sarcophagi, the subject of Hermes would be appropriate for a funerary monument, given the god’s role as Psychopompos, in which he led the deceased to the underworld.

The subject of Hermes, Io, and Argus appears in a similar composition on a number of Roman wall paintings as well as on a relief from the Julio-Claudian Sebasteion at Aphrodisias. The closest comparison, which includes all three main figures, is found in a panel from the fourth-style wall paintings from the temple of Isis at Pompeii (fig. 20.11). Although the figures are arranged differently than those of the Chicago panel, with the seated figures on opposite sides of the scene, it is apparent that they reflect a common model.

While this interpretation finds considerable merit in identifying the three main figures with a recognizable scene, numerous questions still remain, including the identities of the standing, cloaked men in the background and the function of the horse and fragmentary man at the far right. Nevertheless, it is likely that the composition as a whole would have been recognizable to the ancient viewer, particularly when combined with the scenes on the other three sides, with which it might have shared some thematic relationship. Above all, based on the large scale and extensive figural decoration on this side panel, it is apparent that the complete sarcophagus was a lavish and costly funerary monument, which was undoubtedly viewed as an attractive and appropriate form of commemoration for the deceased.  
Katharine A. Raff

To be sure, the Chicago panel exhibits some minor variations from the Autun panel, which leads one to question whether the same subject matter was intended. For example, the central figure of the Chicago panel is depicted with long, luxurious hair, which is atypical for Meleager, who more frequently is shown with shorter, albeit wavy locks. Moreover, Meleager is not typically shown in this pose, with one leg elevated. On the representation of Meleager, see Woodford and Krauskopf, “Meleagros,” esp. p. 415, cat. 3, pl. 208. On the Meleager statuary type, see Stewart, Skopas of Paros, pp. 104–07, 142–44, 151; see also cat. 4, Statue of Meleager, fig. 4.4. Additionally, Atalanta is typically shown fully clothed in hunting garb, wearing a short chiton reminiscent of that of Artemis, the Greek goddess of the hunt (the Roman Diana). For an image of Atalanta wearing the short chiton, see the Meleager sarcophagus in the Palazzo Doria Pamphilj in Rome, which is illustrated in cat. 4, Statue of Meleager, fig. 4.6. However, on occasion Atalanta is shown in Roman domestic frescoes wearing a fitted, revealing chiton, in which she more closely resembles Aphrodite, the Greek goddess of erotic love (the Roman Venus); see Lorenz, “Image in Distress?,” pp. 329–30.

Vermeule, “Dated Monuments,” p. 176; Vermeule, “Relief with Herakles.” Andrew Stewart built upon this interpretation, noting that the seated female figure might be the nymph Thetis, who, along with Herakles, would have been considered the ancestors of Alexander; see Stewart, Faces of Power, p. 116. However, Koch argued that Alexander would be an unusual choice for a sarcophagus, as would his representation with Herakles and a nymph; see Koch, “Zu einem Relief in der Alsdorf Foundation,” p. 129.

However, the Alexander Rondanini type has also been interpreted as a possible image of Achilles; see Ridgway, Hellenistic Sculpture, vol. 1, p. 139 n. 14; Stewart, Faces of Power, p. 115. Vermeule, “Relief with Herakles”; Vermeule, “Roman Art,” p. 76, cat. 35. Following this interpretation, Vermeule identifies the seated figure on the left as Herakles, presumably based on his nudity, muscular body, and club. See also Boardman, Palagia, and Woodford, “Herakles,” p. 825, cat. 1578, for a similar identification as Herakles. However, Herakles does not appear to have been one of the heroes who joined Meleager in this conquest, as their only encounter appears to have occurred when Herakles descended to the underworld, where he met Meleager’s shade; see Bacchylides, Epinician Odes, 5.68–175.

Sandra Knudsen to the Art Institute of Chicago, Oct. 22, 2015, curatorial object file, Art Institute of Chicago. On Io, see Dowden, “Io.” On the representation of Io, see Yalouris, “Io (I).” On Hermes’s rescue of Io from Argus, see Ovid, Metamorphoses 1.568–746.

However, the long, wavy hairstyle depicted here is atypical for Hermes, who typically wears short, somewhat curly locks. On the representation of Hermes, see Siebert, “Hermes.”

For more on this motif, see Smith, Aphrodisias, vol. 6, p. 240.

On Hermes as Psychopompos, see Jost, “Hermes,” p. 690. Paul Zanker and Björn Ewald suggested that the figure of Hermes was also intended to be significant to the contemporary viewer, as his presence could remind the mourner to overcome their anguish and return to the world. Hermes is shown in this capacity on a sarcophagus from Ostia, now in the Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek, Copenhagen (847), in which he encourages Helios to move on after the death of his son, Phaeton. On this sarcophagus, Hermes is similarly shown standing with one leg raised, although he is facing a different direction. For a discussion of this sarcophagus, see Zanker and Ewald, Living with Myths, pp. 82, 390–92, fig. 70.

Hermes does not appear in all of the wall paintings, nor does he appear on the relief from the south building of the Julio-Claudian Sebasteion at Aphrodisias. In these cases, Argus is instead represented as the standing figure, who is shown facing Io. Roger Ling described the scene with three figures as “an uncomfortable hybrid between the Nician composition and a separate iconography for the handing over of the pipes, reflected in other paintings from Pompeii and Herculaneum”; see Ling, Roman Painting, p. 133. For examples of wall paintings illustrating Io’s captivity, see Yalouris, “Io (I),” pp. 667, 668, 669, cats. 36–38, 61 (Io, Argus, and Hermes), 45–51 (Io and Argus), pls. 444–47. See also Museo Nazionale di Napoli, Le collezioni, vol. 1, pp. 146–47, cats. 162–63; Ling, Roman Painting, pp. 37, 113, 128, 129, 130, 132–33; Sampaolo, “VII 14, 5. Casa del Banchiere o della Regina d’Inghliterra,” p. 683, cat. 44; Sampaolo, “Tempio di Iside (VIII 7, 28),” p. 825, cat. 188. A painting of Io by Nikias is mentioned by Pliny (Natural History, 35.132); see Ling, Roman Painting, pp. 128, 130. However, it is unclear whether it depicted the same scene as represented in the aforementioned examples. On the relief from the south building of the Julio-Claudian Sebasteion at Aphrodisias, which depicts Io, Argus, and perhaps Hera, see Smith, Aphrodisias, vol. 6, pp. 239–40, cat. D 29, fig. 190, pls. 134–35.

On the wall painting depicting Hermes rescuing Io from her captivity by Argus (Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Napoli, Naples, 9548), see Sampaolo, “Tempio di Iside (VIII 7, 28),” p. 825, cat. 188.

To this point, see Smith, Aphrodisias, vol. 6, p. 240. A similar scene, albeit lacking the seated male figure, is found on a stucco relief panel in the underground basilica near the Porta Maggiore in Rome. This scene has been identified variously as representing Orestes and Iphigenia, Orestes and Electra, or Theseus and Ariadne. For an overview of the various interpretations, see Mingazzini, “Sul Preteso Carattere Religioso,” p. 102, pl. 45.1. I thank Nicola Barham for suggesting this comparison.

The standing, cloaked men do not appear in any of the wall paintings or the marble relief depicting Argus, Io, and Hermes. With regard to the partially preserved horse and man at the right corner, their placement suggests that they figured instead into the front panel of the sarcophagus. Perhaps both corners of the front panel included bridled horses led by male figures, such as the Dioscuri, as one finds on the sarcophagus from Sidamara. As the “patron saints of the dead,” the Dioscuri would similarly have been an appropriate subject for a sarcophagus; see Elderkin, “Sarcophagus of Sidamara,” pp. 106–07. I am grateful to Sandra Knudsen for her observation that the fragmentary man at the right corner might be identified as one of the Dioscuri.
